choices.text: Thymus and inferior parathyroid gland
Thymus and superior parathyroid gland
Only superior parathyroid glands
Only inferior parathyroid glands

questions.text: Given below is a picture of the pharyngeal pouches and arches. Which of the following structures are arises from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymus and inferior parathyroid gland

 

Option A:

 

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch gives rise to both the thymus and inferior parathyroid gland. This developmental origin explains their close proximity in the neck.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Thymus and superior parathyroid gland. Incorrect. The superior parathyroid gland arises from the 4th pharyngeal pouch, not the 3rd.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parathyroid glands develop from the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. The thymus also develops from the third pouch. As it descends, the thymus takes the associated parathyroid gland with it, which explains why the inferior parathyroid, which arises from the third pharyngeal pouch, normally lies inferior to the superior gland.

 

The developing thyroid lobes amalgamate with the structures that arise in the fourth pharyngeal pouch, i.e., the superior parathyroid gland and the ultimobranchial body.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 850

choices.text: Thyro-thymic tract
Near upper pole

questions.text: What is the most common site for ectopic inferior parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thyro-thymic tract

 

Option A:

 

This is the correct answer. The thyro-thymic tract refers to the path of descent that the inferior parathyroid glands follow during embryonic development, from the third pharyngeal pouch down to their final position near the lower poles of the thyroid gland. It is common for ectopic parathyroid glands to be found along this tract, which may extend into the thymus, hence the term 'thyro-thymic.'

 

Most common site of ectopic parathyroid is thyro-thymic tract. Usually the inferior parathyroids are in abnormal location, due to longer descent.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Intra-thyroidal - While parathyroid glands can be found within the thyroid gland itself, this is less common than in the thyro-thymic tract.

 

Option C: Near upper pole - Parathyroid glands are generally located near the poles of the thyroid gland. However, the 'near upper pole' is not the most common site for ectopic parathyroid glands. Typically, the superior parathyroids are located near the upper pole of the thyroid, while the inferior parathyroids are located near the lower pole.

 

Option D: Mediastinal - Mediastinal ectopic parathyroid glands are those that have descended past the normal location into the chest cavity. This is a less common site for ectopic glands compared to the thyro-thymic tract but is still a possible location for ectopic inferior parathyroid glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for ectopic inferior parathyroid glands is the thyro-thymic tract, reflecting the embryological descent of these glands from the third pharyngeal pouch.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Fig 56.1

choices.text: Tumour lysis syndrome
Parathyroid Adenoma
Secondary hyperparathyroidism
Multiglandular Parathyroid hyperplasia

questions.text: A 45 years old postmenopausal woman, presented to the OPD with back pains. Initial screening shows serum calcium levels of 11.7mg%, Vit. D is 55 ng/ml and elevated PTH. What might be the most common cause of such clinical manifestations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parathyroid Adenoma

 

Option B:

 

Elevated serum calcium and PTH with normal Vit. D Levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Causes:

 

  1. PTH secreting adenoma: M/C cause
  2. Multiglandular hyperplasia: seen in MEN syndrome

 

Parathyroid Adenoma - A parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of a parathyroid gland that causes primary hyperparathyroidism. It results in the overproduction of PTH, which in turn can lead to hypercalcemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tumour Lysis Syndrome - This condition occurs when a large number of tumor cells are lysed rapidly, releasing their contents into the bloodstream. This can lead to hypercalcemia due to the high influx of intracellular calcium into the bloodstream. This is seen in setting of chemotherapy for leukemias, which does not match the clinical scenario. In this case, PTH levels would not be elevated.

 

Option C: Secondary Hyperparathyroidism - This condition arises due to another disease that causes low calcium levels, prompting the parathyroid glands to overproduce PTH to compensate. Common causes include chronic kidney disease and vitamin D deficiency, which are not indicated in this patient due to her normal vitamin D levels.

 

Option D: Multiglandular Parathyroid Hyperplasia - This refers to the enlargement and increased activity of more than one parathyroid gland. It's often seen in genetic conditions such as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) syndromes. While this could cause elevated PTH levels, it is less common than a single adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A parathyroid adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by elevated PTH and calcium levels, with normal vitamin D levels, especially in the context of a postmenopausal woman with back pains.

 

Causes of hypercalcemia:

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 875

questions.text: All of the following are seen in symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skin rash

 

Option D:

 

Skin rash is not typically associated with PHPT. The classical symptoms are related to the effects of high calcium levels on bones, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and the central nervous system.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Renal calculi - Renal calculi are a common manifestation of primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT). The condition can lead to hypercalcemia, which in turn can cause calcium to precipitate in kidneys leading to calcium oxalate stones.

 

Option B: Painful bones - Patients with PHPT can experience bone pain and skeletal fragility. This is due to excess PTH stimulating bone resorption, which can lead to osteitis fibrosa cystica, a condition where bones become weak and deformed.

 

Option C: Mental confusion - Elevated calcium levels associated with PHPT can result in neuropsychiatric manifestations, including mental confusion, fatigue, depression, and memory impairment, often referred to as "psychiatric moans"

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skin rash is not a typical manifestation of symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, which is classically characterized by symptoms involving the bones, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and central nervous system, summarized by the phrase ‘painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, fatigue overtones and psychiatric moans’.

 

  • Patients are typically identified incidentally with elevated total calcium or following routine assessment of bone densitometry (DEXA scan).
  • Most patients will, however, have some vague constitutional symptoms, such as fatigue, muscle weakness, depression or some mild memory impairment on questioning.
  • The presence of kidney stones remains the most common clinical manifestation of symptomatic PHPT.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. PG 875

choices.text: Decreased urinary excretion of phosphate

questions.text: All of the following will be seen in the biochemical panel of a patient with primary Hyperparathyroidism except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased urinary excretion of phosphate

 

Option C:

 

In a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT), the following findings would typically be observed in a biochemical panel:

 

Decreased urinary excretion of phosphate

 

This is incorrect in the context of PHPT. Typically, increased PTH levels lead to decreased renal reabsorption of phosphate, resulting in increased urinary excretion of phosphate, not decreased.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypercalcemia - This is a hallmark feature of PHPT due to the overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to increased calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, increased calcium release from bones, and increased calcium absorption from the intestine.

 

Option B: Normal serum creatinine - PHPT does not necessarily affect renal function; therefore, serum creatinine levels may remain within normal ranges unless there is concomitant kidney disease.

 

Option D: Increased serum ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase) - Serum ALP may be elevated in PHPT if there is bone involvement. PTH stimulates bone turnover, which can raise ALP levels as it is an enzyme associated with bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In primary hyperparathyroidism, the biochemical profile usually includes hypercalcemia, normal serum creatinine, increased urinary excretion of phosphate, and possibly increased serum alkaline phosphatase if bone disease is present. Decreased urinary excretion of phosphate is not a feature of PHPT.

 

  • PHPT is a biochemical diagnosis. Only when the disease has been confirmed biochemically should localization studies be undertaken.
  • PHPT is defined as an elevated total, or more specifically ionized, calcium in the presence of an inappropriately elevated or unsuppressed PTH.
  • It is associated with a low serum phosphate in the setting of normal creatinine and vitamin D levels; 24-hour urinary excretion of calcium may be normal or elevated.
  • It is important to perform a 24-hour urinary collection to rule out the presence of the rare familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH).
  • Alkaline phosphatase may be elevated in patients in whom there is concomitant bone disease.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 876

choices.text: 4D CT scan neck

questions.text: A 50 years old female was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. USG neck revealed a single adenoma of the left parathyroid gland. What’s the most preferred technique to determine its localization?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

 

Option D:

 

The use of Sestamibi (2-methoxy-2-methylpropylisonitrile [MIBI]) for parathyroid localisation was first described in 1989 and is now regarded as the most accurate and reliable method for imaging the parathyroid glands. It is safe and reproducible and, while it has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultra-sonography, it may image glands in ectopic positions better

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Preoperative localisation studies for PHPT were considered less important than identifying an experienced surgeon. However, with a shift away from the traditional four gland (cervical neck) exploration to more minimally invasive procedures, accurate preoperative identification is critically important to guide surgical strategy

 

Option B: Selective venous sampling for PTH can allow accurate localisation of adenomas but an experienced interventional radiologist is vital for success.

 

Option C: Multiphase CT imaging (4D-CT) has become widely utilized to localise disease. It gives both anatomical and functional information about the parathyroid gland. The potential disadvantage of 4D-CT scanning is the higher radiation dose when compared with traditional imaging modalities.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed., Pg. 875, 876

questions.text: In total parathyroidectomy for multi-glandular disease, all 4 parathyroid glands are removed and bits are re-implanted in which part of the body?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Forearm

 

Option C:

 

In the surgical treatment of multi-glandular parathyroid disease, particularly when a total parathyroidectomy is performed, the various sites for auto-transplantation of parathyroid tissue are considered based on accessibility and the ability to monitor and potentially resect the tissue if hyperparathyroidism recurs.

 

Auto-transplantation into the non-dominant forearm, specifically into the brachioradialis muscle, allows for easy monitoring of the graft function and also facilitates re-operation if there is recurrent hyperparathyroidism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Sternocleidomastoid muscle - This is not a common site for auto-transplantation of parathyroid tissue. While it is easily accessible during neck surgery, it is less preferred due to the potential for difficulty in monitoring and resecting the tissue if necessary.

 

Option B: Behind the thyroid gland - Re-implantation behind the thyroid gland is not a standard practice because it can make it challenging to distinguish between recurrent disease in the neck and the transplanted tissue.

 

Option D: Abdomen - Although the abdomen is a site that could technically be used for transplantation, it is not preferred due to the complexity of re-operation in this area and the inability to easily monitor the graft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In total parathyroidectomy for multi-glandular parathyroid disease, the standard practice is to re-implant small pieces of parathyroid tissue into the brachioradialis muscle of the non-dominant forearm to facilitate monitoring and potential future re-operation.

 

  • “All four glands can be resected and a forearm auto-transplant created. Small pieces of parathyroid are sutured into pockets created in the brachioradialis muscle of the non-dominant forearm.”

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 880

choices.text: Brachioradialis muscle of non-dominant forearm
Brachioradialis muscle of dominant forearm
All 4 glands are reimplanted in normal anatomical locations

questions.text: A 67 years old male underwent a total thyroidectomy for papillary carcinoma of the thyroid gland. The parathyroid glands were accidentally removed. Where can the surgeon re implant these glands?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sternocleidomastoid

 

Option C:

 

  • If the parathyroid glands are accidentally removed during thyroid surgery, they can be re-implanted into the sternocleidomastoid muscle. This keeps the parathyroid tissue in the neck, allowing for a more physiological parathyroid function and potentially easier surgical access if there are problems in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the parathyroid glands are inadvertently removed during thyroidectomy, they may be re-implanted into the sternocleidomastoid muscle to maintain more physiological parathyroid function and allow for surgical accessibility if needed in the future.

 

  • In total parathyroidectomy for “multiglandular hyperplasia”, all four glands can be resected and a forearm auto-transplant created. Small pieces of parathyroid are sutured into pockets created in the brachioradialis muscle of the non-dominant forearm. This will allow easier diagnosis of recurrence of hyperparathyroidism

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Pg 880

choices.text: More than half the maximum pre-operative value in 30 mins
More than half the maximum preoperative value in 10 mins
More than one third the maximum preoperative value in 30 mins
More than one third the maximum pre-operative value in 10 mins

questions.text: A 37-year-old female patient is undergoing a focused parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered appropriate, the intra operative drop in parathyroid hormone level should be around?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) More than half the maximum pre-operative value in 10 mins

 

Option B:

 

When performing a focused parathyroidectomy for a parathyroid adenoma, the intraoperative measurement of parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels is crucial to confirm the successful removal of the adenoma.

 

More than half the maximum preoperative value in 10 mins - This is the correct answer according to the Miami criteria. A significant drop in PTH levels to less than half of the highest pre-operative value within 10 minutes post-excision suggests successful removal of the hyperfunctioning gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami criteria were developed to determine the extent of resection. A drop in the PTH into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes appears to accurately predict single-gland disease.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 880

choices.text: Serum calcium 0.5 mg% above upper limit/dL
DEXA Scan T score -2.5 at lumbar spine

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was undergoing routine scanning when he was diagnosed with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism. All of the following are criteria for surgical intervention in a case of primary HPTH except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serum calcium 0.5 mg% above upper limit

 

Option B:

 

The guideline for surgical intervention typically requires a serum calcium level that is more than 1 mg% above the upper limit of normal. A smaller elevation, such as 0.5 mg%, does not usually indicate the need for surgery in asymptomatic patients.

 

In the management of asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPTH), indications for surgical intervention include several criteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Age < 50 years - This is one of the indications for surgery. Younger patients are more likely to benefit from surgical intervention due to the potential for longer-term complications of the disease if left untreated.

 

Option C: DEXA Scan T score -2.5 at lumbar spine - A T-score of -2.5 or lower at any major site (lumbar spine, hip, or forearm) is an indication for surgery because it reflects significant bone loss, which could be attributable to HPTH.

 

Option D: 24-hour urinary calcium >10 mmol/dL - This indicates increased calcium excretion, which increases the risk for kidney stones, and is a criterion for considering surgery in the management of HPTH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, surgical intervention is indicated for patients younger than 50 years, those with a serum calcium more than 1 mg% above the upper limit of normal, a DEXA scan T-score of -2.5 or less at any major site, or a 24-hour urinary calcium excretion greater than 10 mmol/dL.

 

  • Serum calcium should be more than 1 mg% above upper limit of normal.
  • In patients not fulfilling below criteria, medical management can be tried for asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 879

questions.text: All of the following are components of MEN 1 syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Option A:

 

 Medullary thyroid carcinoma - This is not a component of MEN 1 syndrome. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is typically associated with MEN 2 syndrome. MEN 1 primarily involves parathyroid, pancreatic, and pituitary tumors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Multi-glandular parathyroid gland hyperplasia - This is a classic feature of MEN 1. Almost all patients with MEN 1 develop parathyroid hyperplasia, leading to primary hyperparathyro

 

Option C: Insulinoma - Insulinomas are pancreatic endocrine tumors that can occur as a part of MEN 1. Although less common than gastrinoma, they are one of the characteristic features of this syndrome.

 

Option D: Prolactinoma - Prolactinomas are pituitary tumors that often occur in MEN 1. They are the most common type of pituitary adenomas found in this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is not a component of MEN 1 syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic endocrine tumors (like gastrinomas>insulinomas), and pituitary tumors (commonly prolactinomas).

 

  • MEN type 1 is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome consisting of tumors of the parathyroids, endocrine pancreas and the pituitary (the three Ps).
  • It can also be associated with adrenal adenomas or carcinoma, foregut carcinoids and lipomas.
  • Men 1 is a tumour suppressor gene. Mutations of MEN 1 gene coding for MENIN protein are responsible for MEN 1.
  • Patients typically present with young onset (20–30 years of age) of symptomatic hyperparathyroidism and over 95% of patients will have PHPT before the age of 40 years.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 882

questions.text: Which is the most common feature of MEN 2A syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medullary thyroid cancer

 

Explanation

 

  • MEN type 2A consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), unilateral or bilateral pheochromocytomas and PHPT due to multiglandular disease.

  • PHPT occurs in approximately 20% of patients and is associated with mutations in codon 634 in the RET proto-oncogene.

 

MEN 2 syndrome:

 

  • Medullary Thyroid carcinoma (90-100%)

  • Pheochromocytoma (10-60%)

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 882

choices.text: Mucosal neuromas belong to MEN 3 syndrome
MEN syndrome is more common at an older age
MEN 4 syndrome is associated with a cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor CDKI mutation
Tumors are aggressive and bilateral in nature

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement with respect to MEN syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MEN syndrome is more common at an older age

 

Option B:

 

MEN syndrome is more common at an older age - This is the incorrect statement. MEN syndromes typically present at a younger age, often with symptoms manifesting in individuals between 20–30 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mucosal neuromas belong to MEN 3 syndrome - Mucosal neuromas are a feature of MEN 2B, which is also referred to as MEN 3 by some classifications. MEN 2B includes medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, and a marfanoid habitus.

 

Option C: MEN 4 syndrome is associated with a cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor (CDKI) mutation - This is correct. MEN 4 is associated with mutations in the CDK inhibitor genes, which can lead to a phenotype similar to MEN 1, with tumors in multiple glands.

 

Option D: Tumors are aggressive and bilateral in nature - This is generally true for MEN syndromes, where tumors can be aggressive and often present bilaterally, especially in the case of pheochromocytomas in MEN 2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN syndromes are characterized by the early onset of tumors in multiple endocrine glands, with familial autosomal dominant inheritance. MEN 2B, sometimes referred to as MEN 3, includes mucosal neuromas. MEN 4 involves CDKI mutations, and MEN syndromes often feature aggressive and bilateral tumors. MEN syndromes are not more common at an older age; they usually present in younger individuals, often before the age of 40.

 

MEN SYNDROME

 

  • Familial disorders, AD inheritance
  • Aggressive, B/L, At younger age
  • Associated with multiple malignancies

 

MEN 1:

 

MEN 1 gene coding for MENIN PROTEIN

 

  • P: Pituitary tumours: Non-functional or Functional (Prolactinoma)
  • P: Parathyroid tumours: M/C feature of MEN 1 (80 %-100 %) due to Multiglandular hyperplasia
  • P: Pancreatic Tumours: Non-functional or functional (Gastrinoma)

 

MEN 4:

 

Cyclin Dependent Kinase inhibitor mutation. Rest same as MEN 1

 

MEN 2 SYNDROME

 

RET Mutation:

 

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90-100%)
  • Pheochromocytoma (10-60%)

 

 Sub-Types: MEN2A and MEN2B/3

 

  • MEN2A: Also has hyperparathyroidism due to multiglandular disease.

 

Prophylactic Thyroidectomy by the age of 5 year

 

  • MEN 2B/3:

 

Also has ‘MMM’: Marfanoid Habitus, Mucosal Neuromas, Mega colon /Hirschsprung: Prophylactic Thyroidectomy by the age of 1 year

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 882-883

choices.text: Seen in MEN 1 syndrome
Tumor shows warm modularity on thyroid scan
Diarrhea is commonly seen due to serotonin secretion
Familial variant is multifocal and bilateral

questions.text: Choose the true statement about medullary thyroid cancers?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Familial variant is multifocal and bilateral

 

Option D:

 

Familial variant is multifocal and bilateral - This is true. The familial form of MTC, as part of MEN 2 syndrome, is often multifocal and bilateral and can be more aggressive than the sporadic form Familial cancers tend to be more aggressive compared to sporadic cancers. Moreover, MEN syndromes are often bilateral and appear at a younger age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Seen in MEN 1 syndrome - This statement is false. Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is not seen in MEN 1 syndrome; instead, it is a characteristic of MEN 2 syndrome.

 

Option B: Tumor shows warm modularity on thyroid scan - This is typically not true for MTC. Thyroid scans, which often use radioiodine, typically do not show uptake in MTC because the C cells do not absorb iodine. These tumors are often "cold" nodules on the scan.

 

Option C: Diarrhea is commonly seen due to serotonin secretion - While diarrhea is a symptom of MTC, it is not common (Seen in <30%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The familial variant of medullary thyroid cancer is often multifocal and bilateral, associated with MEN 2 syndrome, and tends to present at a younger age compared to sporadic cases.

 

  • Medullary thyroid cancers are tumours of the parafollicular (C cells) derived from the neural crest that are not unlike those of a carcinoid tumour.
  • High levels of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced. Calcitonin levels fall after resection and rise again with recurrence, making it a valuable tumour marker in the follow-up of patients with this disease.
  • Diarrhea is a feature in 30% of cases and this may be due to 5-hydroxytryptamine or prostaglandins produced by the tumour cells.
  • Medullary carcinoma may occur in combination with adrenal phaeochromocytoma and hyperparathyroidism (usually due to hyperplasia) in the syndrome known as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN-2A).
  • The familial form of the disease frequently affects children and young adults, whereas the sporadic cases occur at any age with no sex predominance.
  • The highest risk mutations are associated with early-onset disease and prophylactic total thyroidectomy is recommended during childhood.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 870-871

choices.text: Hyperparathyroidism is seen in MEN 1 and MEN 2B
Gastrinoma is the most common functional endocrine tumor of pancreas in MEN 1
Pheochromocytoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement about MEN syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperparathyroidism is seen in MEN 1 and MEN 2B

 

Option B:

 

The Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) syndromes are characterized by the occurrence of tumors in multiple endocrine glands.

 

Hyperparathyroidism is seen in MEN 1 and MEN 2B - This statement is incorrect. Hyperparathyroidism is commonly seen in MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not MEN 2B. MEN 2B is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas, without hyperparathyroidism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Autosomal dominant inheritance - This is correct. MEN syndromes are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

 

Option C: Gastrinoma is the most common functional endocrine tumor of the pancreas in MEN 1 - This is true. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumor in MEN 1, often leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

 

Option D: Pheochromocytoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B - This is correct. Pheochromocytoma is a feature of both MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that hyperparathyroidism is a feature of MEN 1 and MEN 2A, not MEN 2B. MEN syndromes are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, and specific tumors are associated with each subtype.

 

MEN (Autosomal dominant) Syndrome:

 

  1. MEN 1: Pituitary + Parathyroid + Pancreas
  2. MEN 2A: MTC + Pheochromocytoma + Parathyroid hyperplasia
  3. MEN 2B: MTC + Pheochromocytoma + Mucosal neuromas

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 882

questions.text: Choose the most common tumour arising from adrenal gland?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Non-functional adenoma

 

Option A:

 

Non-functional adenoma - These are the most common type of adrenal tumor. Non-functional adenomas are usually benign and do not secrete hormones, so they often do not cause symptoms and are found incidentally during imaging studies for other reasons, hence the term "incidentaloma."

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Cushing’s adenoma - These are functional adenomas that produce cortisol, leading to Cushing’s syndrome. They are less common than non-functional adenomas.

 

Option C: Pheochromocytoma - This is a rare tumor that arises from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla and produces catecholamines, leading to episodes of hypertension, palpitations, and headaches. They are less common than non-functional adenomas.

 

Option D: Metastasis - While the adrenal glands are a common site for metastasis from other primary tumors, such as lung and breast cancer, this is not a primary tumor of the adrenal gland itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common tumor arising from the adrenal gland is the non-functional adenoma, often discovered incidentally on imaging studies.

 

  • An asymptomatic adrenal mass detected on imaging not performed for suspected adrenal disease is termed an incidentaloma.
  • The types include benign and malignant tumours of the cortex and medulla or of extra-adrenal origin.
  • These tumours can be either non-functioning (silent) or functioning (secreting excess hormones).
  • Radiological features suspicious of adrenal malignancy
    • Diameter > 40 mm and > 10 HU density
    • Contrast-enhanced washout CT
    • MRI chemical shift: no change in signal intensity on out-of-phase imaging
    • FDG-PET: positive uptake

 

Management:

 

  • All patients should be discussed in a multidisciplinary setting.
  • Adrenalectomy is the standard of care for patients with unilateral tumours causing hormone excess (functional adenomas).
  • Adrenalectomy is recommended for all tumours > 40 mm in diameter, tumours showing imaging characteristics of malignancy and tumours showing significant growth.
  • Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is recommended for unilateral adrenal masses with radiological findings suspicious of malignancy and a diameter < 6 cm without local invasion.
  • Small (< 40mm) benign non-functioning tumours do not require surgery, but patients should undergo a follow-up CT/MRI at 6 months.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 890

questions.text: What is preferred investigation modality for localisation of pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRI

 

Option B:

 

MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) - MRI is a preferred modality for imaging pheochromocytoma due to its superior soft tissue contrast, which helps in the identification and characterization of these tumors, particularly when they are located in the adrenal glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound) - EUS is not typically used for the localization of pheochromocytoma. It is more commonly used for gastrointestinal lesions and for assessing the pancreas.

 

 

Option C: DOPA PET (Dihydroxyphenylalanine Positron Emission Tomography) - While DOPA PET scans can be very sensitive for detecting pheochromocytoma, especially when other imaging is inconclusive, they are not the first-line investigation due to cost and availability.

 

Option D: MIBG Scan (Metaiodobenzylguanidine Scan) - MIBG scans are highly specific for pheochromocytoma, particularly for extra-adrenal and metastatic disease. However, they are usually reserved for when initial imaging with CT or MRI is inconclusive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred initial imaging modality for localizing pheochromocytoma is MRI, due to its detailed soft tissue imaging capabilities, which are beneficial for assessing tumor size and the risk of malignancy.

 

  • Once a biochemical diagnosis is established, imaging by CT or MRI is undertaken to determine tumour location and assess its size and risk of malignancy. Size is not a predictor of malignancy for pheochromocytoma.
  • Malignant Pheochromocytoma and Paragangliomas (PPGLs) are diagnosed by the presence of local invasion or metastatic disease. Tumours appear vascular and frequently possess cystic areas or central necrosis.
  • If initial imaging is negative or reveals extra-adrenal disease, functional investigation with 123I-MIBG (meta-iodo benzyl guanidine; 80–90% sensitive) or 111 In-octreotide scanning (50–70% sensitive) is undertaken. Routine use is not advocated in well-localised adrenal lesions.
  • More recently, 6-[18F] Fluoro-dopamine PET scanning has shown promise, particularly in the setting of PGLs, where conventional imaging and MIBG scanning are negative.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 900-901

choices.text: Plasma dopamine levels positive
Decreased 24 hours’ urinary excretion of fractionated metanephrine

questions.text: A 55 years old patient presented with severe headache, palpitations and sweating. On CECT abdomen, an adrenal tumour was detected. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased 24 hours’ urinary excretion of fractionated metanephrine

 

Option C:

 

Triad of pheochromocytoma: Headache + Palpitations + Sweating

 

In a patient with symptoms of severe headache, palpitations, and sweating, and an adrenal tumor detected on imaging, the following findings are expected in pheochromocytoma:

 

Decreased 24 hours urinary excretion of fractionated metanephrine - This is unlikely to be seen in a case of pheochromocytoma. Typically, there is an increased excretion of metanephrines in the urine, as they are metabolites of catecholamines.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Elevated plasma catecholamines - This would likely be seen in a patient with a pheochromocytoma, as these tumors secrete high levels of catecholamines, leading to the classic triad of symptoms.

 

Option B: Plasma dopamine levels positive - Elevated plasma dopamine can be seen in certain cases of pheochromocytomas, especially malignant ones, as it can be a marker of tumor burden.

 

Option D: Elevated urinary catecholamines - Elevated urinary catecholamines would be expected in a patient with a pheochromocytoma, as the tumor secretes catecholamines that are metabolized and excreted in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of an adrenal tumor and symptoms of headache, palpitations, and sweating, increased levels of urinary metanephrines are typical and help confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.

 

  • Increased 24 hours’ urinary excretion of fractionated metanephrine seen.
  • The diagnosis of Pheochromocytoma is confirmed by elevated catecholamine metabolites (metanephrine) in plasma and/or raised 24-hour urinary excretion of fractionated metanephrines.
  • Measurement of plasma and urinary metanephrines is more sensitive (99% and 97%, respectively) than plasma and urinary catecholamine measurement (86% and 84%, respectively).
  • Measurements of one or more of these substances that are four times greater than the upper limit of the reference range are 100% diagnostic.
  • Plasma dopamine can be regarded as a marker of tumour burden in malignant PPGLs.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 900

choices.text: 10% are extra adrenal

questions.text: Which of the following does not fit into the 10% rule of pheochromocytomas?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 10% are unilateral

 

Option A:

 

10% are unilateral - This is incorrect because the majority of pheochromocytomas are unilateral. The "10% rule" states that 10% are bilateral, not unilateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "10% rule" for pheochromocytomas suggests that approximately 10% are bilateral, inherited, extra-adrenal, malignant, and occur in children, which means that stating 10% are unilateral does not fit this rule.

 

Rule of 10% for pheochromocytomas:

 

  • 10% are bilateral
  • 10% inherited
  • 10% extra-adrenal (Organ of Zuckerkandl)
  • 10% malignant
  • 10% occur in children.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 899-900.
